title: Micah Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Micah chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Micah Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Micah Chapter 7.

questions.question: In Micah 7:1, what does the speaker compare himself to?
options: The grapegleanings of the vintage
A mighty warrior
A flowing river
A burning fire
questions.correctAnswer: The grapegleanings of the vintage
questions.explanation: Micah 7:1 compares the speaker to the grapegleanings of the vintage, indicating scarcity and desolation.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:2, what has perished out of the earth?
options: The good man
The kings
The prophets
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: The good man
questions.explanation: Micah 7:2 states that the good man is perished out of the earth, indicating a time of moral decay.

questions.question: What do the prince and judge ask for according to Micah 7:3?
options: A reward
Peace
Wisdom
Forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: A reward
questions.explanation: Micah 7:3 indicates that the prince and judge ask for a reward, showing corruption.

questions.question: How does Micah describe the best and most upright people in Micah 7:4?
options: As a brier and sharper than a thorn hedge
As angels and pillars of strength
As wise sages and teachers
As pure gold and precious stones
questions.correctAnswer: As a brier and sharper than a thorn hedge
questions.explanation: Micah 7:4 compares the best and most upright to a brier and sharper than a thorn hedge, indicating they are difficult and troublesome.

questions.question: Micah 7:5 warns to not trust in which of the following?
options: A friend and a guide
A stranger and a merchant
A king and a prophet
A priest and a teacher
questions.correctAnswer: A friend and a guide
questions.explanation: Micah 7:5 advises not to trust in a friend or put confidence in a guide, highlighting betrayal.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:6, who are described as a man's enemies?
options: The men of his own house
Foreign nations
The priests
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The men of his own house
questions.explanation: Micah 7:6 states that a man's enemies are the men of his own house, indicating family strife.

questions.question: What will the speaker do in Micah 7:7?
options: Look unto the LORD and wait for God of salvation
Flee to the mountains
Build a strong city
Gather a mighty army
questions.correctAnswer: Look unto the LORD and wait for God of salvation
questions.explanation: Micah 7:7 expresses the speaker's resolve to look unto the LORD and wait for salvation.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 7:8 says that when the speaker falls, he will not arise.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 7:8 says when the speaker falls, he shall arise; thus, the statement is false.

questions.question: In Micah 7:9, what will the LORD do after the speaker bears His indignation?
options: Plead the speaker's cause and execute judgment
Send a flood
Bring darkness upon the land
Punish the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Plead the speaker's cause and execute judgment
questions.explanation: Micah 7:9 states the LORD will plead the speaker's cause and execute judgment after the speaker bears His indignation.

questions.question: What will the enemy see and be covered with shame according to Micah 7:10?
options: The LORD's deliverance of the speaker
A great army
A mighty fortress
The destruction of the land
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD's deliverance of the speaker
questions.explanation: Micah 7:10 explains the enemy will see the LORD's deliverance of the speaker and be covered with shame.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 7:12 says that help will come from Assyria and fortified cities.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Micah 7:12 states that help will come from Assyria and other fortified cities to the people.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:13, why shall the land be desolate?
options: Because of the fruit of their doings
Because of a great famine
Because of wild animals
Because of a drought
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the fruit of their doings
questions.explanation: Micah 7:13 states the land shall be desolate due to the fruit of the inhabitants' actions.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Micah 7:14: 'Feed thy people with thy _______, the flock of thine heritage.'
options: rod
sword
staff
shield
questions.correctAnswer: rod
questions.explanation: Micah 7:14 says, 'Feed thy people with thy rod,' indicating God’s guidance and discipline.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 7:18 describes God as one who retains anger forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 7:18 states God does not retain His anger forever because He delights in mercy, so the statement is false.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:20, to whom has God sworn mercy?
options: Abraham
Moses
David
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham
questions.explanation: Micah 7:20 says God will perform mercy to Abraham as He has sworn to the fathers from days of old.

medium.title: Micah Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Micah Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting others due to past betrayals. Based on Micah 7, what biblical truth would you share about trust?
options: Trust not in a friend or guide, but in God alone
Always trust your closest friends implicitly
Trust only those who have never failed you
Avoid trusting anyone to protect yourself
questions.correctAnswer: Trust not in a friend or guide, but in God alone
questions.explanation: Micah 7:5 warns against trusting even close friends or guides because of widespread betrayal, teaching us to put our ultimate trust in God (Micah 7:5, 7:6).

questions.question: How does Micah 7:7 teach us about perseverance in prayer during difficult times?
options: Look to the LORD and wait patiently for His salvation
Pray only when things are going well
Give up praying if answers don’t come quickly
Rely on your own strength without seeking God
questions.correctAnswer: Look to the LORD and wait patiently for His salvation
questions.explanation: Micah 7:7 encourages believers to patiently look to the LORD for salvation and trust that God hears their prayers, teaching perseverance in faith and prayer (Micah 7:7, 7:8, 7:9).

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity can be learned from Micah 7:3?
options: Leaders may seek bribes and promote evil, so integrity is essential
It is acceptable for judges to accept rewards for favors
Doing evil with both hands is a sign of power
Leaders should remain silent about wrongdoing
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders may seek bribes and promote evil, so integrity is essential
questions.explanation: Micah 7:3 shows that princes and judges often seek bribes to do evil, highlighting the need for integrity and honesty in leadership and daily life (Micah 7:3, 7:4).

questions.question: A Christian parent is concerned about family strife. What does Micah 7:6 teach about family relationships and how should they respond?
options: Family conflicts can be severe, but God’s love can restore unity
Family members will always live in harmony
Ignore conflicts because they will resolve themselves
Prioritize work over family to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Family conflicts can be severe, but God’s love can restore unity
questions.explanation: Micah 7:6 describes deep family discord, reminding believers that while strife may occur, trust in God’s mercy and forgiveness can restore relationships (Micah 7:6, 7:18-19).

questions.question: How does Micah 7:18-19 encourage believers about forgiveness and reconciliation?
options: God delights in mercy and will subdue our iniquities
God holds anger forever and does not forgive
Forgiveness is impossible for repeated sins
Only some sins can be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: God delights in mercy and will subdue our iniquities
questions.explanation: Micah 7:18-19 teaches that God is merciful and will forgive the sins of His people, encouraging believers to seek reconciliation and extend forgiveness (Micah 7:18-19, 7:20).

questions.question: When facing trials and darkness, what hope does Micah 7:8 offer to believers?
options: Even if you fall, you will arise; the LORD will be your light
You will remain in darkness without help
Enemies will always rejoice over your troubles
You must rely on yourself to find light
questions.correctAnswer: Even if you fall, you will arise; the LORD will be your light
questions.explanation: Micah 7:8 provides hope that despite falling or sitting in darkness, God will be a light and strength to believers, encouraging perseverance (Micah 7:8, 7:9).

questions.question: What does Micah 7:14 teach about God’s care for His people and how should believers respond?
options: God shepherds His people and we should follow His guidance faithfully
God abandons those who dwell alone
People must fend for themselves without divine help
Faithfulness is not necessary for God’s care
questions.correctAnswer: God shepherds His people and we should follow His guidance faithfully
questions.explanation: Micah 7:14 depicts God as a shepherd feeding His flock, teaching believers to trust His leadership and remain faithful under His care (Micah 7:14, 7:7).

questions.question: True or False: According to Micah 7:2, there are still many upright and good people living on earth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 7:2 states that the good man has perished from the earth and none is upright, indicating a time of widespread moral failure.

questions.question: How does Micah 7:9 demonstrate the importance of humility and repentance during trials?
options: Bear the LORD’s indignation for sin until He judges and shows righteousness
Ignore your sins and blame others
Avoid admitting fault to protect your reputation
Repentance is unnecessary during hardships
questions.correctAnswer: Bear the LORD’s indignation for sin until He judges and shows righteousness
questions.explanation: Micah 7:9 teaches the need to humbly accept God’s discipline for sin and trust His righteous judgment, encouraging repentance and hope.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:20, what has God promised to Abraham and his descendants?
options: To perform truth and mercy as sworn from days of old
To give them wealth and land without conditions
To remove all trials instantly
To keep them isolated from other nations
questions.correctAnswer: To perform truth and mercy as sworn from days of old
questions.explanation: Micah 7:20 affirms God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises of truth and mercy to Abraham’s descendants, encouraging trust in His enduring commitment.

questions.question: What does Micah 7:4 teach about the condition of even the best people and the need for spiritual vigilance?
options: Even the best are like briers, so watchfulness and repentance are needed
The best people are perfect and without fault
There is no need for repentance if you are good
Only outsiders are harmful, not those inside the community
questions.correctAnswer: Even the best are like briers, so watchfulness and repentance are needed
questions.explanation: Micah 7:4 compares the best people to sharp thorns, indicating imperfection and the necessity of spiritual vigilance and repentance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Micah 7:1, the soul desired the __________ fruit.
options: firstripe
ripe
sweet
bitter
questions.correctAnswer: firstripe
questions.explanation: Micah 7:1 expresses a desire for the firstripe fruit, symbolizing a longing for goodness that is lacking.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:10, what will happen to those who mock the LORD’s presence in the believer's life?
options: They will be covered with shame and trodden down like mire
They will be blessed and honored
They will be ignored without consequence
They will quickly repent without shame
questions.correctAnswer: They will be covered with shame and trodden down like mire
questions.explanation: Micah 7:10 describes how enemies who mock God's presence will experience shame and be humbled, illustrating divine justice.

questions.question: How does Micah 7:17 illustrate the power of God over nations and the effect on His people?
options: Nations will fear the LORD and be afraid because of His people
Nations will dominate and oppress God’s people
God’s people will be powerless against other nations
Nations will unite against God’s people
questions.correctAnswer: Nations will fear the LORD and be afraid because of His people
questions.explanation: Micah 7:17 shows that nations will be humbled and fear God because of His people’s witness and God’s power.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 7:16 says the nations will confidently speak with full strength before God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 7:16 states that the nations will be confounded, silent, and deaf, indicating fear and awe rather than confidence.

hard.title: Micah Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Micah Chapter 7.

questions.question: In Micah 7:2, what is said about the state of humanity and their relationships?
options: The good man is perished out of the earth and none are upright; they lie in wait for blood and hunt their brothers.
People are living in harmony and righteousness, loving their neighbors as themselves.
The earth is full of peace and justice, with judges ruling fairly without bribery.
The children obey their parents and communities are united in faith.
questions.correctAnswer: The good man is perished out of the earth and none are upright; they lie in wait for blood and hunt their brothers.
questions.explanation: Micah 7:2 describes a grim social condition where no one is upright, and people are hostile to each other, hunting their brothers like prey.

questions.question: Micah 7:5 advises not to trust in which of the following?
options: A friend and a guide
The government and kings
Strangers and foreigners
Prophets and priests
questions.correctAnswer: A friend and a guide
questions.explanation: Verse 5 warns against trusting friends and guides, even advising to keep silence from a close one who lies in one's bosom, highlighting betrayal within intimate relationships.

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in Micah 7:6 where family members turn against each other?
options: Parallelism illustrating internal social decay
Chiasm emphasizing reversal of loyalty
Typology foreshadowing Messianic conflict
Allegory of spiritual warfare
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism illustrating internal social decay
questions.explanation: Micah 7:6 uses parallelism to emphasize the breakdown of family trust and the inward social turmoil, a common poetic device in Hebrew prophecy.

questions.question: What is the response of the prophet in Micah 7:7 to the surrounding corruption?
options: I will look unto the LORD and wait for the God of my salvation.
I will build walls to protect myself from enemies.
I will join the corrupt leaders for protection.
I will abandon hope and isolate myself.
questions.correctAnswer: I will look unto the LORD and wait for the God of my salvation.
questions.explanation: Despite societal decay, Micah 7:7 expresses trust and hope in God’s salvation, demonstrating the prophet’s faith and patience.

questions.question: Which phrase from Micah 7:18 highlights God's unique attribute in mercy?
options: "Who is a God like unto thee, that pardoneth iniquity, and passeth by the transgression of the remnant of his heritage?"
"The LORD is a consuming fire, jealous and unyielding."
"The God of hosts is a warrior who destroys his enemies."
"The Almighty sits enthroned in judgment, punishing the wicked."
questions.correctAnswer: "Who is a God like unto thee, that pardoneth iniquity, and passeth by the transgression of the remnant of his heritage?"
questions.explanation: Micah 7:18 marvels at God's unparalleled mercy in forgiving sin and not retaining anger forever, a central theme contrasting divine justice with mercy.

questions.question: Micah 7:14 makes a geographical reference to 'Bashan and Gilead'. What is the significance of these locations in the ancient Near East?
options: They were fertile regions known for pasturelands, symbolizing restoration and provision.
They were cities of pagan worship, representing idolatry.
They were desert wastelands signifying desolation.
They were centers of political power opposing Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: They were fertile regions known for pasturelands, symbolizing restoration and provision.
questions.explanation: Bashan and Gilead were known for rich pastures, and their mention in Micah 7:14 symbolizes God’s promise to feed and restore His people as in the days of old.

questions.question: How does Micah 7:8 reflect a theme of resurrection or restoration found elsewhere in Scripture?
options: It echoes the theme that after a period of darkness or fall, God will bring light and raise up the fallen, similar to Isaiah 60.
It predicts a political uprising against foreign oppressors.
It illustrates the futility of hope in the face of judgment.
It emphasizes human self-reliance rather than divine intervention.
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the theme that after a period of darkness or fall, God will bring light and raise up the fallen, similar to Isaiah 60.
questions.explanation: Micah 7:8’s statement about rising after falling and the LORD being a light parallels the restoration themes found in Isaiah 60 and other prophetic hopeful texts.

questions.question: What historical or cultural context might explain the lament in Micah 7:1 about the absence of fruit to eat?
options: It reflects the devastation of Israel due to war or divine judgment leading to agricultural failure.
It is a metaphor for exile in Babylon where fruits were unknown.
It symbolizes the rejection of foreign idols in the land.
It foretells the coming Messianic banquet.
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the devastation of Israel due to war or divine judgment leading to agricultural failure.
questions.explanation: The lament of no grapes or summer fruits in 7:1 corresponds with the historical reality of destruction and famine often accompanying Israel’s judgment periods.

questions.question: True or False: According to Micah 7:6, a man's enemies are primarily those outside his homeland.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 7:6 states that a man's enemies are the men of his own house, emphasizing internal betrayal rather than external foes.

questions.question: Micah 7:19 uses a metaphor for God dealing with sin. What is it?
options: Casting all their sins into the depths of the sea.
Burning sins with unquenchable fire.
Writing sins on tablets of stone.
Covering sins with a veil of darkness.
questions.correctAnswer: Casting all their sins into the depths of the sea.
questions.explanation: This metaphor in 7:19 illustrates God’s complete forgiveness and removal of sin, similar to imagery found in Psalms 103:12.

questions.question: What does Micah 7:3 reveal about the corruption of leadership in Israel?
options: Princes and judges ask for bribes, and great men express harmful desires.
Leaders are just and uphold the law without favoritism.
Kings and priests work together to protect the poor.
Leaders are absent and powerless against oppression.
questions.correctAnswer: Princes and judges ask for bribes, and great men express harmful desires.
questions.explanation: Verse 3 exposes systemic corruption where leaders pursue evil earnestly and seek rewards, showing moral decay at the top.

questions.question: How does Micah 7:12's mention of Assyria and fortified cities function in the prophetic message?
options: It signifies the widespread return and restoration from exile across diverse regions.
It predicts the fall of Assyria as a foreign oppressor.
It condemns Assyria as an eternal enemy without hope of peace.
It calls for military alliance with Assyria against Babylon.
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies the widespread return and restoration from exile across diverse regions.
questions.explanation: Micah 7:12 portrays a future ingathering of people from distant lands, symbolizing restoration and the fulfillment of divine promises.

questions.question: Which New Testament concept aligns with the hope expressed in Micah 7:9 about being brought forth to the light and beholding righteousness?
options: The resurrection and justification by faith in Christ as the light of the world.
The establishment of the earthly kingdom of Israel under Davidic rule.
The messianic kingdom of peace on earth without judgment.
The complete rejection of the Law and embracing of secularism.
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection and justification by faith in Christ as the light of the world.
questions.explanation: Micah 7:9’s hope of being brought into the light after judgment corresponds with New Testament themes of resurrection and righteousness through Christ, the light of the world (John 8:12).

questions.question: Micah 7:4 compares the best and most upright among people to what imagery?
options: The best is like a brier, and the most upright is sharper than a thorn hedge.
The best is like a fruitful vineyard, and the most upright like a cedar of Lebanon.
The best is like a flowing river, and the most upright like a mountain peak.
The best is like pure gold, and the most upright like a polished gem.
questions.correctAnswer: The best is like a brier, and the most upright is sharper than a thorn hedge.
questions.explanation: This imagery in verse 4 illustrates the harshness and difficulty of the people, even the best among them are like prickly plants causing pain.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:20, to whom does God promise to perform truth and mercy?
options: Jacob and Abraham, as sworn to the fathers from days of old.
Moses and Aaron, the leaders of the Exodus.
David and Solomon, the kings of Israel.
Isaiah and Jeremiah, the prophets of old.
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob and Abraham, as sworn to the fathers from days of old.
questions.explanation: Micah 7:20 affirms God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises made to the patriarchs Jacob and Abraham, emphasizing continuity of divine mercy.

theological.title: Micah Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Micah Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:18, what attribute of God is uniquely emphasized in His dealings with the remnant of His heritage?
options: God delights in mercy and pardons iniquity
God enforces eternal wrath without relent
God rewards according to works
God shows partiality to the strong
questions.correctAnswer: God delights in mercy and pardons iniquity
questions.explanation: Micah 7:18 highlights God's unique mercy and forgiveness, stating He pardons iniquity and does not retain anger forever. This is consistent with Exodus 34:6-7 where God is declared merciful and gracious, Psalm 103:8 emphasizing God's compassion, Isaiah 55:7 calling for repentance due to God's mercy, and Luke 15:7 where Jesus celebrates repentance and forgiveness.

questions.question: In Micah 7:7, what is the prophet's response to the corruption and evil he observes in society?
options: I will look unto the LORD and wait for the God of my salvation
I will seek revenge against my enemies
I will join the corrupt to survive
I will isolate myself from all people
questions.correctAnswer: I will look unto the LORD and wait for the God of my salvation
questions.explanation: Micah 7:7 shows the prophet's trust in God despite societal decay, affirming faith in God's salvation. This aligns with Psalm 27:14 urging to wait on the LORD, Isaiah 40:31 on those who wait renewed in strength, Romans 8:24-25 on hope in salvation, and Hebrews 10:36 encouraging endurance to obtain God's promises.

questions.question: What imagery does Micah 7:1 use to describe the scarcity of good people in the land?
options: Like the gleanings of the vintage with no cluster to eat
Like a river overflowing with fruit
Like a flourishing vineyard with abundant grapes
Like a field full of ripe wheat
questions.correctAnswer: Like the gleanings of the vintage with no cluster to eat
questions.explanation: Micah 7:1 uses the metaphor of harvest gleanings to depict the rarity of the good, indicating scarcity and disappointment. This fits with Proverbs 11:30 about the fruit of the righteous, John 15:5 where Jesus is the true vine, Galatians 5:22 on the fruit of the Spirit, and Revelation 14:18-20 depicting harvest as judgment and salvation.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:6, who are described as a person's enemies?
options: The men of his own house
Foreign nations
Strangers from afar
Political rulers
questions.correctAnswer: The men of his own house
questions.explanation: Micah 7:6 reveals a breakdown of family trust, portraying internal strife where close relatives become enemies. This theme is echoed in Matthew 10:36 about household divisions, Luke 12:53 on family discord, Jeremiah 12:7 lamenting betrayal by kin, and Psalm 55:12-14 describing treachery among friends.

questions.question: What does Micah 7:9 say the LORD will do after the prophet bears His indignation?
options: He will plead the prophet's cause and execute judgment
He will abandon the prophet to darkness
He will increase the prophet's suffering
He will silence the prophet forever
questions.correctAnswer: He will plead the prophet's cause and execute judgment
questions.explanation: Micah 7:9 describes God's justice and vindication after the prophet endures divine discipline. This aligns with Isaiah 54:17 promising no weapon prospering, Romans 8:33-34 about Christ interceding, Psalm 37:5 committing one’s way to the LORD, and Revelation 19:11 on God's righteous judgment.

questions.question: In Micah 7:14, what metaphor is used to describe God's care for His people?
options: Feeding His people with His rod like a shepherd
Building a fortress to protect them
Leading them through fire and flood
Planting them like trees by the river
questions.correctAnswer: Feeding His people with His rod like a shepherd
questions.explanation: Micah 7:14 employs the shepherd imagery to depict God's guidance and discipline of His heritage. This echoes Psalm 23:1-4 where the LORD is Shepherd, Ezekiel 34:11-16 about God seeking His sheep, John 10:11 where Jesus is the Good Shepherd, and Hebrews 13:20 referencing the Shepherd of souls.

questions.question: Which eschatological hope is expressed in Micah 7:8?
options: Though I fall, I shall arise; the LORD shall be a light unto me
The darkness will consume all the righteous
The enemies will triumph forever
Salvation is only for the past generation
questions.correctAnswer: Though I fall, I shall arise; the LORD shall be a light unto me
questions.explanation: Micah 7:8 conveys resurrection and divine illumination despite adversity, a key messianic and eschatological theme. This aligns with Isaiah 60:1 about arising in light, Romans 6:4 on walking in newness of life, 1 Peter 1:3 on resurrection hope, and Revelation 21:23 where God’s light dispels darkness eternally.

questions.question: What does Micah 7:20 affirm God’s covenant faithfulness is based upon?
options: The oath sworn to Abraham and the fathers from ancient days
Human works and rituals
The power of earthly kings
The abundance of sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: The oath sworn to Abraham and the fathers from ancient days
questions.explanation: Micah 7:20 emphasizes God's unchanging covenant promise made to the patriarchs, a foundation of salvation history. This is consistent with Genesis 12:2-3 where God calls Abraham, Exodus 2:24 recalling covenant remembrance, Romans 4:13 on righteousness through faith, and Galatians 3:16 on Christ as the seed of Abraham.

questions.question: How does Micah 7:3 describe the behavior of leaders and judges during this time of corruption?
options: They ask for rewards and express mischievous desires
They faithfully uphold justice without bias
They seek peace among the people
They refrain from any wrongdoing
questions.correctAnswer: They ask for rewards and express mischievous desires
questions.explanation: Micah 7:3 depicts leaders as corrupt, seeking bribes and promoting evil, reflecting a failure of justice. This matches Proverbs 17:23 on bribery corrupting hearts, Isaiah 10:1-2 condemning unjust laws, Jeremiah 5:28 on greedy officials, and James 2:6 warning against favoritism in judgment.

questions.question: What is the fate of the prophet’s enemy according to Micah 7:10?
options: She shall be trodden down as the mire of the streets
She shall be exalted among nations
She shall receive God's mercy
She shall be hidden from all eyes
questions.correctAnswer: She shall be trodden down as the mire of the streets
questions.explanation: Micah 7:10 foretells the disgrace and defeat of the enemy who mocked God's presence. Similar imagery appears in Isaiah 41:15 on being trampled, Psalm 35:8 on enemies falling, Nahum 1:15 on the fall of foes, and Revelation 11:2 on trampling the holy city.

questions.question: Micah 7:4 compares the best and most upright people to what kind of plants?
options: Briers and thorn hedges
Cedars of Lebanon
Olive trees
Vines laden with fruit
questions.correctAnswer: Briers and thorn hedges
questions.explanation: Micah 7:4 uses sharp and painful plants to show even the best people are harmful or difficult, illustrating human sinfulness. This is paralleled in Judges 2:3 on briers and thorns, Hosea 10:8 on thorns and briars, Hebrews 6:8 on thorns in the land, and Matthew 7:16 on false prophets bearing bad fruit.

questions.question: Micah 7:17 describes nations reacting to God's power in what way?
options: They shall be confounded, lay hands on their mouths, and fear the LORD
They shall conquer Israel and boast
They shall ignore God's judgments
They shall unite to oppose God
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be confounded, lay hands on their mouths, and fear the LORD
questions.explanation: Micah 7:17 depicts nations humbled and fearful before God’s mighty acts, a common biblical theme. Isaiah 2:10-11 speaks of trembling before God, Joel 2:11 on the LORD’s fierce army, Nahum 1:5 on mountains melting at God’s presence, and Romans 14:11 on every knee bowing to Christ.

questions.question: What does Micah 7:19 say God will do with the sins of His people?
options: Cast all their sins into the depths of the sea
Remember their sins forever
Punish their sins publicly
Ignore their sins completely
questions.correctAnswer: Cast all their sins into the depths of the sea
questions.explanation: Micah 7:19 uses the metaphor of casting sins into the sea to express complete forgiveness. This is consistent with Isaiah 38:17 on removing sins, Psalm 103:12 on removing transgressions far from us, Jeremiah 31:34 on forgiving iniquity, and Hebrews 8:12 on God remembering sins no more.

questions.question: What warning is given in Micah 7:5 about trusting others?
options: Do not trust a friend or put confidence in a guide
Trust all people unconditionally
Rely solely on human wisdom
Ignore deceit and be open
questions.correctAnswer: Do not trust a friend or put confidence in a guide
questions.explanation: Micah 7:5 warns against misplaced trust even in close relationships due to pervasive deceit. Similar warnings appear in Psalm 41:9 on betrayal, Jeremiah 9:4 on false friends, Proverbs 24:21 on fearing the LORD over man, and John 13:21 on Judas’s betrayal.

questions.question: According to Micah 7:12, from where will help come in the day the walls are rebuilt?
options: From Assyria and fortified cities to the river, sea, and mountains
Only from local tribes nearby
From Egypt alone
From Babylon exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: From Assyria and fortified cities to the river, sea, and mountains
questions.explanation: Micah 7:12 predicts a vast restoration including aid from Assyria and distant places, indicating divine providence over nations. This aligns with Isaiah 19:23-25 about nations coming to worship God, Zechariah 10:10 on gathering exiles, Psalm 72:8 on dominion from sea to sea, and Revelation 7:9 on a great multitude from all nations.
